discourse_list.title: Should governance polls include a gantt chart?

content.content: A Gantt chart is a type of bar chart that shows all the tasks constituting a project. Tasks are listed vertically, with the horizontal axis marking time. The lengths of task bars are to scale with tasks’ durations. It typically includes two sections: the left side outlines a list of tasks, while the right side has a timeline with schedule bars that visualize work. The Gantt chart can also include the start and end dates of tasks, milestones, dependencies between tasks, and assignments. A visual gantt chart would allow voters and the community to have a high-level view of the project’s most important tasks, task owners and deliverable timelines. Voters can also assess if the poll initiative has been thought through and the team is set up for execution. content.content: This implies that all Core Units utilize Gantt charts in their process, which is not true. In fact, I think it would lead to micromanagement and would add unnecessary overhead to the org. In my opinion accountability should be managed on Core Unit level—not on proposal/initiative level.

Introducing standardized estimates (forecasts) and improving their accuracy is something that needs to be built bottom-up. It requires a significant effort and coordination between core units. We are not at an organizational maturity level that is required for it and we will need to improve our cross-core unit coordination processes first.

content.content: How is providing a high-level timeline of rolled-up expected activities for an initiative that has passed MIP and put through for MKR holders voting not at a minimum recommended? It’s not intended as micro-managing, but for shareholder transparency. No forecast is right (read: ETH merge) and we know things will change, but providing directional transparency at a higher level can provide a lot of value at the time of voting. And yes, after the poll passes, accountability will be up the CUs to uphold, and there is no penalty for missing deadlines and timelines can be adjusted as CU members seek.     ultraschuppi:  would be funny to have a poll like “do you want the developers to code faster on XYZ”    Even a very conservative deadline for an initiative that will most likely impact DAO’s performance should be considered. “A goal without a plan is a just a wish”

content.content: If you work out an example, you will see the issues I believe. Which MIP should have a Gantt chart in your opinion? What would it look like? MIPs today express MKR holders’ preferences rather than Core Units’ proposed project plans. Exceptions are CU MIP39s and MIP40s, but they should be more high-level than what allows for a Gantt chart, or you will get micro-management. Roadmaps and plannings on the level of Gantt charts should be fluid working documents, not cemented in MIPs. Or we will run into all the typical issues around waterfall project management. If we want to shift to project-based funding (and that’s a big if), the general structure of these cross-core unit collaborations should be worked out first. And then a planning may be part of the documentation. But right now your proposal is trying to strap a horse saddle on a bicycle.

content.content: Well, this shows it quite clearly:   As a status update from the related core units a visualization like this would make sense and is in fact being used, for example for the L2 initiative. As @MakerMan is saying, this would show work that’s already in the pipeline, which is very much needed.   MIP65 is not owned by the core units but by the external business partner. The external partner can’t determine the planning of the core units. That depends on the on-going work that core units have.   Should core units spend a significant amount of time making estimates for a business partner that hasn’t passed the vote yet? Probably not.   Even if MIP65 were to have a section that contains the core units’ planning, they wouldn’t be able to show a timeline due to dependencies. For example if 3 MIP65s get approved, that’s going to take more time than if only one passes the vote. So how can a planning be made part of the vote if the planning itself depends on the vote’s outcome?   So in summary, I think your ask for an indication of the work that comes with collateral onboarding is very reasonable. However, at the stage of a poll, a Gantt chart isn’t the right tool for this. Better questions would be:   How can we get a rough estimate of the associated work, and therefore cost, of collateral on-boarding MIPs? So that MKR holders and delegates can make an informed decision. (Without spamming CUs)   How can we get the visualization of the process for collateral onboarding right?   How can we better report on the ongoing work of core units?   How can we estimate timelines (forecasts) and get better at estimating?   This is an example for the L2 roadmap:      Collecting information on on-going work will fit within the decentralized operations initiative and the result will be published on the Ecosystem Performance Dashboard These are long-term solutions. In the meantime @gov-comms-core-unit and others have put some time in collecting the ongoing initiatives. It would be great to bring that together in one place until the dashboard can replace that.

content.content: Yes, it is very very simple and no need for the reader to have expertise on the topic to get a sense of how the team is feeling about the project’s progress. Gantt charts are great when you really know every task that needs to be performed in the project and make a decent estimation on it. I do like Christian’s point on understanding how the counterparty knows what they are getting into and using that as a first estatement of the work that each side envisions. There is a benefit there for sure, but it can easily lead to micromanagement in the open working mode we have in the DAO. I guess it is just a matter of creating a working culture that prevents micromanagement and inspires openness.
